UTM Standout Sweeton Signs With Broncos 

Martin, Tenn. ‚Äì Former University of Tennessee at Martin football standout Charles Sweeton has been signed by the Denver Broncos, as announced by the team over the weekend.

After injuries riddled Denver‚Äôs offensive line early in training camp, the Broncos turned to Sweeton, a 6-5, 291-pound left tackle out of Lawrenceburg, to help provide depth and protection for a team which finished 12-4 last season behind five-time Most Valuable Player, Peyton Manning. 

Sweeton was a mainstay on the Skyhawk offensive line, starting in all 46 games of his collegiate career. He graded out at 88 percent or better in every game in his final two seasons and conceded only one sack during that span. He was a 2014 Preseason All-American and blocked for a dynamic UT Martin offense that averaged 30.2 points per game during his career (2011-14).

This is Sweeton‚Äôs second NFL opportunity this offseason after initially signing with the Kansas City Chiefs as an undrafted free agent on May 11. 

The Skyhawks currently have four former players on active NFL rosters in Sweeton (Broncos), Abou Toure (Indianapolis Colts), Jeremy Butler (Baltimore Ravens) and Montori Hughes (Indianapolis Colts).

By Jeff Harrison
August 3, 2015

The early 1960s continue to dominate the selections for the Martins Ferry Athletic Hall of Fame's Class of 2015. Today, we take a look at Ted Torok (Class of 1961) and Joe Minder (Class of 1962).

Ted Torok
 (Class of 1961)
A talented blocker and tackler on the interior line, he was a key member of the 1960 team which fashioned a perfect 10-0 record, won the OVAC Class AAA championship and was ranked No. 8 in Ohio. 
The 6-4, 215-pound Torok received several post-season accolades as a senior including second team Class A All-Ohio defensive tackle; first team All-OVAC, All-Eastern Ohio and All-Valley.
While at Ferry High, he was a four-year member of the football and basketball teams; a three-year performer in track and a one-year member of the baseball team.
 He went on to the University of Virginia where the 6-5, 250-pound offensive tackle was a three-year letterman and team captain as a senior, playing under Coach Bill Elias, a native of Martins Ferry.
After receiving a tryout with the NFL‚Äôs Baltimore Colts, he played five years (1965-69) with the Norfolk Neptunes of the Continental Football League.

Joe Minder
(Class of 1962)
A four-year football letterman, he was a fixture on the offensive line for three-and-a-half seasons. He moved into the starting lineup for the last four games of his freshman year and remained their for the rest of his prep grid career. He started nearly every one of the games during the Purple Riders‚Äômemorable 32-game winning streak which netted Ferry High three OVAC football championships.
Minder was part of the popular ‚ÄúFive Tons of Fun Plus One‚Äù which also included Phil Ward, Bill Lude, Frank Stauffer, Larry Duck plus quarterback Charlie Coss. A team co-captain as a senior, he was an All-OVAC and All-Valley ‚ÄúBig School‚Äù selection.
In track, he was a three-year letterman and a co-captain as a senior, with his specialty the discus throw where he set the school record of 141 feet, 7 inches as a junior and qualified for the state meet as a senior. He also participated in wrestling for two years.
He went on to West Virginia University on a football scholarship, playing offensive line for three years. Later, he obtained his degree from West Liberty State College. Minder entered the coaching fraternity in the mid-1960s, first as an assistant football coach at St. John Central and soon thereafter as the head track coach for five years. Minder spent nine years as Martins Ferry‚Äôs Recreation Director followed by 13 years as Service/Safety Director and was a member of the Martins Ferry Board of Education for several years. He passed away in 2003.

from.name: Martins Ferry High School Hall of Fame

August 3, 2011: Bubba Smith was found dead in his Baldwin Hills, California home by his caretaker. He died from acute drug intoxication and heart disease. Phentermine, a weight-loss drug, was found in his system. His heart weighed more than twice that of an average human heart. He was 66 years old.

Charles Aaron "Bubba" Smith was a professional football player who became an actor after his retirement from the sport. He first came into prominence at Michigan State University, where he twice earned All-American honors as a defensive end on the Spartans football team. He had a major role in a 10‚Äì10 draw with Notre Dame in 1966 that was billed as "The Game of the Century." 
He was one of only three players to have his jersey number retired by the program. He was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1988.

He played nine years in the NFL with the Baltimore Colts (1967‚Äì1971), Oakland Raiders (1973‚Äì1974) and Houston Oilers (1975‚Äì1976). The first selection of the 1967 NFL Draft, he was the Colts' starting left defensive end for five seasons who played in Super Bowls III and V, the latter with the winning side. He was named to two Pro Bowls and was a First-Team All-Pro in 1971. Despite being 6 feet 7 inches tall and weighing 265 pounds, his tremendous speed and quickness usually caused him to draw two blockers.

During his acting career, he mainly specialized in comedic roles in films, television advertisements and programs. For about a decade following his retirement from football, he appeared in various commercials for Miller Lite. His best-known role was as Moses Hightower in the first six Police Academy movies.

Show me the records and Facts or STFU! Wilson is the first QB in NFL history with a passer rating of over 95.0 in each of his first three seasons.

- Wilson has 24 games with a passer rating of 100+ in his first three seasons...more than any other QB in NFL history. Flacco, Marino, and Palmer are tied for second with 19.

- Wilson leads all QB‚Äôs in the NFL over the last 3 years with 10- 4th quarter comebacks and 15- game-winning drives. No other QB in NFL history has ever done this in their first 3 years.

- He is one of only five players with at least 20 touchdown passes in each of first three seasons.

- Wilson is the first and only QB in the Super Bowl era to have average yards per attempt of 7.6 or better in each of his first three seasons.

- Wilson‚Äôs career yards per passing attempt of 7.9 is fourth-best of all QB‚Äôs since 1951.

- Wilson is ranked #1 in career postseason yards per attempt. His career average of 9.01 (min. 200 pass attempts) is the highest in NFL history.

- Wilson is the only QB in NFL history to appear in two SB's in his first three seasons.

- Wilson holds the record for most passing yards in a playoff game by a rookie QB with 385 yards. The old record was set in 1937 by Sammy Baugh with 335 yards...that record stood for 75 years.

- Wilson is ranked at #2 in all-time career passer rating (min. 1200 attempts) with a 98.6. Only Aaron Rodgers has a higher career passer rating.

- Wilson's passer rating of 98.6 for a player‚Äôs first 3 years is the best in NFL history.

- Including postseason, Wilson's passer rating of 98.5 for a player's first three years is the best in NFL history.

- Wilson's postseason passer rating of 97.8 in his first three years is the best in NFL history.

- Wilson‚Äôs career postseason passer rating of 97.8 (min. 200 attempts) is the 5th best in NFL history.

- Wilson's TD% of 5.8% in his first three years is the 2nd highest in NFL history; only Dan Marino is higher with 6.9%.

- Wilson's INT% of 2.1% in his first three years is the lowest of any QB in NFL history.

- Wilson is ranked #2 all-time with a career TD to INT ratio of 2.77 (min. 1200 attempts) behind only Rodgers.

- Wilson is ranked #3 all-time with a career INT rate of only 2.1%, behind only Rodgers and Brady.

- Wilson is the first and only QB in NFL history to throw for 300+ yards and run for 100+ yards (313 & 106) in the same game...against the Rams on 10-19-14.

- Only one QB in NFL history had more than one season with more than 20 TD passes and 10 or fewer interceptions in his first three seasons: Wilson, who has had three such seasons.

- His 72 touchdowns are the seventh-most ever through a player‚Äôs first three seasons.

- Including the postseason, Wilson has 84 passing TD's in his first three seasons, 4th-most in NFL history.

- Including the postseason, Wilson has 97 passing and rushing TD's in his first three seasons, 3rd-most in NFL history.

- Wilson is ranked #12 all-time for most passing yards by a QB in his first three years with 9950 yards.

- Including the postseason, Wilson is ranked #5 all-time for passing yards by a QB in his first three years with 11770 yards.

- Wilson is ranked #5 all-time for most total yards (passing + rushing) by a QB in his first three years with 11827 yards.

- Including the postseason, Wilson is ranked #2 all-time for most total yards (passing and rushing) by a QB in his first three years with 13902 yards.

- Wilson has the 2nd highest career yards per attempt in SB history with 9.85 yards, behind only Terry Bradshaw.

- Wilson has the 3rd highest career passer rating in SB history with a 117.39, behind only Joe Montana and Jim Plunkett.

- Wilson has the 6th highest career completion % in SB history with 65.22%.

- Wilson has the 4th highest yards per attempt in a SB game with 11.76 yards in SB49.

- Wilson's 1,877 rushing yards is second-most by a QB in the modern era through three seasons behind Cam Newton's 2,032 yards.

- Including the postseason, Wilson has the most rushing yards for a QB in NFL history in his first three seasons with 2132 yards.

- Wilson led all NFL rushers in 2014 with an average of 7.2 yards per carry.

- Wilson has a record of having had a lead at some point in 56 straight games since 2012...the old record was 45 games...Also, in those 56 games, Wilson has never lost an NFL game by more than 9 points.
